lines.text: [last lines]
So... your adventures are over.
Oh, no. To live... to live would be an awfully big adventure.

[sees Tinkerbell on the Peter Pan statue]
Tink!
Say it, Peter. Say it and mean it.
I believe in fairies.
You know that place between sleep and awake? That place where you still remember dreaming?
[Peter nods]
That's where I'll always love you... Peter Pan. That's where I'll be waiting.
Prepare to die, Peter!
To die would be a grand adventure!
Death is the only adventure you have left!

[to Rufio, who pulls a sword at him]
Okay, mister. All right, show's over. Now, you put that thing away! Now, put it down before you poke somebody's eye out.
[the Lost Boys all laugh]

You're not old enough to shave! What are you doing with a sword? And flying around... this is an insurance nightmare! What is this, some sort of "Lord of the Flies" preschool? Where are your parents? Who's in charge, here?
[the Lost Boys all point to Rufio, who bows]
No! No, Mr. Skunkhead with too much mousse. You are just a punk kid. I want to speak to a grown-up!
All grown-ups are pirates!
Excuse me?

[smiles]
We kill pirates.
I'm not a pirate. It so happens I am a lawyer.
Kill the lawyer!

[drawing their weapons]
Kill the lawyer!

[backs away nervously]
I'm not that kind of lawyer...
I've just had an apostrophe.
I think you mean an epiphany.

[gestures his fingers to his head]
Lightning has just struck my brain.
Well, that must hurt.

[holding a pistol to his head]
No stopping me this time, Smee. This is it. Don't make a move Smee, not a step. My finger's on the trigger. Don't try to stop me, Smee.
Oh, not again.

This is it. Don't try to stop me this time, Smee. Don't try to stop me this time, Smee. Don't you dare try to stop me this time, Smee, try to stop me. Smee, you'd better get up off your arse. Get over here, Smee!
I'm coming. I'm coming.
Stop me! This is not a joke! I'm committing suicide!
[Smee triggers the gun away from Hook's head, sinking the model ship in the pool]
Don't ever frighten me like that again.
I'm sorry.
What are you, some kind of a sadist?
I'm sorry, I'm sorry. How do you feel now?

[sighs]
I want to die.
Oh, now, now.
There's no adventure here.

[hold out Hook's gun]
You call this no adventure?
Death is the only adventure I have left, Smee.

[Searching for something on the floor]
Lost, lost, lost.
Lost what?
I've lost my marbles.

[after throwing Peter's cell phone out the window]
I'm sorry about your deal.
You hated the deal.

I hated the deal, but I'm sorry you feel so badly about it. Your children love you, they want to play with you. How long do you think that lasts? Soon Jack may not even want you to come to his games. We have a few special years with our children, when they're the ones that want us around. After that you're going to be running after them for a bit of attention. It's so fast Peter. It's a few years, and it's over. And you are not being careful. And you are missing it.
[Peter recalls a memory from his childhood]
Peter, I can't come with you. I've forgotten how to fly. I'm old, Peter. Ever so much more than twenty. I grew up a long time ago.
No, no, no! You promised!
I have children of my own now. They have children of their own. That's my grandchild, Moira, asleep in the bed.

[voiceover]
When I saw her lying there sleeping, that moment, something changed in me forever.
I shall give her a kiss.
[takes out a thimble]
No. No, Peter. No buttons. No thimbles. I couldn't bear to see Moira's heart to be broken when she finds she can't keep you.
No. I mean a real kiss.
Well, whoever you are it's still you, 'cause only one person has that smell.
Smell?

The smell of someone who has ridden the back of the wind, Peter. The smell of a hundred fun summers, with sleeping in trees and adventures with Indians and Pirates. Oh remember, Peter? The world was ours. We could do everything or nothing. All it had to be was anything 'cause it was always us.
Boil-dripping beef, fart-sniffing bubble butt!
Bangarang, Rufio!
Someone has a severe ca-ca mouth, you know that?
You are fart factory, slug-slimed, sack-of-rat-guts-in-cat-vomit, cheesy, scab-picked, pimple-squeezing finger bandage. A week old maggot burger with everything on it and flies on the side!

[in unison]
Ugh!
Substitute chemistry teacher.
Come on, Rufio, hit him back.
Mung tongue.
Math tutor.
Pinhead.
Prison barber.
Mother lover.
Nearsighted gynecologist.
In your face, camel cake!
In your rear, cow derrière.
Lying, crying, spying, prying ultra-pig.
You lewd, crude, rude, bag of pre-chewed food dude.

[with the rest of the Lost Boys]
Bangarang, Peter!
You... you man! Stupid, stupid man!
Rufio, if I'm a maggot burger why don't you just eat me! You two-toned zebra-headed, slime-coated, pimple-farmin' paramecium brain, munchin' on your own mucus, suffering from Peter Pan envy!
What's a paramecium brain?
I'll tell you what a paramecium is! That's a paramecium! It's a one-celled critter with no brain, that can't fly! Don't mess with me man, I'm a lawyer!

[chanting]
Banning, Banning, Banning is bangerang.
Rufio! Rufio!
Oh, Rufio, why don't you just go suck on a dead dog's nose.
I remember you being a lot bigger.
To a ten year-old I'm huge.
Oh, I hate being disappointed, Smee. And I hate living in this flawed body. And I hate living in Neverland. And I hate... I hate... I *hate* Peter Pan!

You're a... you're a complex Freudian hallucination having something to do with my mother and I don't know why you have wings, but you have very lovely legs and you're a very nice tiny person and what am I saying, I don't know who my mother was; I'm an orphan and I've never taken drugs because I missed the sixties, I was an accountant.
Guess again.
[Tinkerbell takes the sheet which makes Peter trip on the floor]

[disoriented]
Oh, look, stars.
That's right, Peter, second star to the right and straight on till morning.
[Tinkerbell takes Peter by the strings of the sheet]
Neverland!
What's the deal? Where's the real food?
If you can't imagine yourself being Peter Pan, you won't *be* Peter Pan, so eat up.
Eat what? There's nothing here. Gandhi ate more than this.
He'll crow. He'll fight. He'll fly. And then... he'll die.
Hear me, men. For reasons of good form, I have decided that the so-called Pan will return in three days to commit the arbitrament of the sword. Smee, translate.
In three days, we're gonna have a war! A battle between good and evil to the death!

[to Peter as he traps him and grinds his hook near his face]
You know you're not really Peter Pan, don't you? This is only a dream. When you wake up, you'll just be Peter Banning - a cold, selfish man who drinks too much, is obsessed with success, and runs and hides from his wife and children!

[with the Lost Boys as they get Peter in shape]
Pick 'em up! Move 'em down! Pick 'em on up! Move 'em on down! Ain't no time to celebrate! You are old and overweight! Gotta lose a million pounds! Get your fat butt off the ground! Reach on down and touch your toes! How long since you looked at those? Shape up! Lose weight! Get thin! Gotta win! Jumping jacks are good for you! Now your face is turning blue! Swing your arms around your back! Give yourself a heart attack! Gotta train! In the rain! In the sun! In the snow! Ten below! Gotta move! Gotta do! Gotta crow!
Hook, you let those kids out of that net in less than one minute or you better get an attorney and hope to God he's better than me.
Who are you?
I'm Peter Banning, Attorney at Law, these are my children and I want them back.
These are your...
Children.
These are your children.
Yes they are.
And you are?
Peter.
You're Peter?
Yes?
You're Peter?
Yes.
No.
Yes.
You're Peter?
Yes. Is there an echo in here? Yes.
My great and worthy opponent?
Yes.
No! Smee, who is this impostor?

[the Lost Boys don't believe Peter Banning is Peter Pan, but Pockets touches his face and finally recognizes him]
Oh, there you are, Peter!

[arriving at Wendy's home, knocks on the door]
Remember, you're in England, land of good manners.
[the door opens, to old man behind the door]
Toodles!
It's snowing!
[slams the door closed on the Bannings]
Boy, why are you crying?
I don't know. A tear for every happy thought.
So, Peter, you've become a pirate.

[singing]
The stars are all my friends / Till the nighttime ends / So I know I'm not alone / When I'm here, on my own. / Isn't that a wonder? / When you're alone / You're not alone / Not really alone.
[Encountering Tinkerbell for the first time]
Firefly from hell.

[yells after Peter who is leaving with Jack, Maggie, and the Lost Boys]
Peter! Where are you going? Come back here and fight me! Or I'll find you wherever you are, you hear me? Bad form, Peter, come back!
You need a mother very, very badly!

[unearthing his cell phone]
Wow. Brad, hi! You been holding this long? Uh huh. I'm incredible. Yeah, Neverland. Uh-huh. Lost Boys. Jim Hook, duel to the death. I'll fill you in later. Listen, I'd love to chat, but I gotta climb a drain pipe right now. Why? Because I ran out of fairy dust, if not I would've flown up.
[surprised he asks]
Why?

[over the airplane intercom]
Hello Ladies and Gentlemen this is your Captain speaking...

[leaving the room after putting Maggie and Jack to bed]
Dear night-lights, protect my sleeping babes. Burn clear and steadfast tonight.
Who is that, Captain?
It's Peter Pan. Has it been three days? 'Tis true, Peter, time does fly. And so do you, I see.

[to Tinkerbell who is fighting off the pirates]
Are you related to Mighty Mouse?
Peter, can I talk to you?
Sure, Thud.
I remember Tootles.
You do?
He was lost too.
How could you know Tootles?
He was a Lost Boy.
[Thud Butt takes out a small pouch]
These are his marbles. These are his happy thoughts.
[Peter empties out the pouch of marbles into his hand and laughs]
He really did lose his marbles, didn't he?

[laughs]
Yeah, he lost them good.
[they both laugh]
Peter, you know what?
What?
My happy thought will help you.
What's your happy thought, Thud?
Mine's my mother. Do you remember your mother, Peter?
Wish I could.

[while seeing Peter fighting a pirate, smiles]
Peter Pan's my... dad?

[after getting stabbed by Captain Hook]
Do you know what I wish?
What?
I wish I had a dad... like you.

[tearfully]
Oh, Dad, I'm sorry.
Good Mooooooooooooorning, Neverland! Tie down the main mast, mateys, 'cause here he is, the cunning kingfish, the bad barracuda! A man so deep, he's almost unfathomable.
[pirates stare blankly]
A man so quick, he's even fast... asleep!
[pirates cheer]
Thank you! Now, let's give him a very big hand, 'cause he's only got one.
[pirates laugh]
I give you, the steel-handed stingray, Captain James Hook!
I have waited long to shake your hand with this. Peter Pan, prepare to meet thy doom!
[draws sword]

[draws sword]
Dark and sinister man, have at thee.
I believe in you, Peter Pan.
Jack, Maggie, all you have to do is think one happy thought, and you'll fly like me.
Mommy.
My dad, Peter Pan.
He's stealing second!
[the catcher shoots the base stealer with his pistol and the crowd cheers]
No, no, no! Now stop it! We're playing this game by Master Jack's rules. Bad form! Sit down, now. Let's resume the game.
[to his lady]
A very violent sport, isn't it, baseball?
But Jack says you're not the really real Wendy.

Ahh. Well, do you see where Jack is, hmm? Well, that is the same window and this is the same room where we made up our bedtime stories about Peter and Neverland and scary old Captain Hook. And did you know? Mr. Barrie - well, Sir James, our neighbor - he loved our stories so much, he wrote them all down in a book, oh dear me, eighty years ago.
You're really old.
That's very true.

[after Peter rescues her and Jack from Captain Hook]
Daddy, let's go home, please? He's just a mean old man without a mommy.
Yeah, dad, let's go. He can't hurt us anymore.
Rufio! Rufio! Ru-Fi-OOOOOOOOOOOOOh!

[as Wendy in the play]
Boy, why're you crying?
I was crying because I couldn't get my shadow to stick, besides I wasn't crying.

[flying from Neverland with his children]
Thank you for believing.

[sits at the dinner table and clasps hands together for prayer]
Everybody say Grace.
Bless this, O Lord...
[quickly grab at the food all at once]
You, the cute little urchin in the front row, won't you share your thoughts with the whole class?
Yes!I said mommy reads to us every night, because she LOVES us very much!
Loves you? Isn't that the, uh, the...
The 'L' word, Captain.
Ooh, yes!
[grimly chuckles]
He took my toy! She hit my bear! I want a potty! I want a cookie! I want to stay up! I want, I want, I want, me, me, me, me, mine, mine, mine, mine, now, now, now, now!
[inhales deeply]
Can't you understand, child? They tell you stories to shut you up.
-And conk you out.
That's not true, Jack!
[to Hook]
You're a liar!

[laughs]
Lie? Me? Never.
[inhales deeply again]
The TRUTH is far too much fun.
Wait, ain't you - ?
Peter Pan.
[Pirate jumps out the window]

The stories are true! I swear to you! I swear on everything I adore, and now he's come back to seek his revenge. The fight isn't over for Captain James Hook. He wants you back. He knows that you'll follow Jack and Maggie to the ends of the earth and beyond. And by heaven, you must find a way. Only you can save your children. Somehow, you must go back. You must make yourself remember.
Remember what?
Peter, don't you know who you are?
[Wendy opens up the book and shows an illustration of Peter Pan as Peter looks in disbelief]

[whispers]
Yes, boy. Yes.
Have to fly, have to fight, have to crow, have to save Maggie, have to save Jack, Hook is back.
Who?
What would the world be like without Captain Hook?
Smee, Smee. What About Smee? Smee! Smee! Smee. Smee. What about Smee? Smee's me. What about me?

[to the lost boys]
Let's get ready to show them the white light we're made of, boys.

[to the pirates]
Remember the fires of hell that forged you. Charge.
I do not believe in fairies.
Every time someone says 'I do not believe in fairies', somewhere there's a fairy that falls down dead.
I DO NOT BELIEVE IN FAIRIES!
[Tinkerbell falls down the stairs of the dollhouse unconscious]
Oh my God, I think I've killed it.
What is this?
[she points to Jack's baseball mitt]
Oh, it's a baseball glove. You can catch things with it, take hot things out of the oven, or you can even hit your sister with it.
[holding up a sign reading "Run Home Jack"]
Run home, Jack! Run home, Jack!
"Run home, Jack."
Smee, no, no, no! They've got it backwards! Tell them to turn it around!
Maggie?
Switch!
[the pirates fix the sign to read "Home Run Jack." They read it]
Home run, Jack! Home run, Jack! Home run, Jack!

[in unison with the other Lost Boys]
Peter Pan?
That ain't Peter Pan.
He's old!
He's fat!
Not so fat to me.

[laughs]
He's an old fat grandpa man.
Put your faces on, girls! Here comes Smee!
Smee?
Smee!
Well, my stupid, sorry, parasitic sacks of entrails...
[the pirates laugh]
...revenge is mine.
[the pirates cheer]
Long live the Hook!
Gentlemen, I'm afraid I have decided to cancel the war. Kill them. Kill them all.
He's Peter Pan or I've got a dead man's dinghy.

[hearing Maggie singing "When You're Alone"]
Mum sang that song.
I drank poison for you! You called me Tink.
You!
[pointing at someone in the crowd]
You! That's right you! No not you! not you... you... You! You bet against me bringing Pan back here, didn't ya?

[Intimidated]
No.
Ahh
[Nods disbelievingly]
... tell your captain the truth
[Breaks down crying]
Awww... say it... say it
I did...
Yes... you made a boo boo...
I did... I did it...
Mmm...
[Looks at another pirate]
The boo box.
Not that! Not the boo box!

[nods]
The boo box.
NOOOOOO!
Yes.

[to Peter, in disbelief]
Is it you? My great and worthy opponent? But it can't be. Not this pitiful, spineless, pasty, bloated codfish I see before me. You're not even a shadow of Peter Pan.

[watching Peter try - and fail - to rescue his children]
Smee, I don't understand. Why doesn't he fly? Is he not Peter Pan?
He's Peter Pan, all right, Captain. He's just been away from Neverland so long, his mind's been junk-tified. He's forgotten everything.

[to Hook]
You killed Rufio, you kidnapped my children. You deserve to die.

[falls to his knees holding his sword up in his hands]
You are the Pan.
[Peter takes the sword from him, draws a line in the sand between him and Rufio and all the lost boys run over to stand behind him. Rufio stands up walks towards him]

[very pleased]
You can fly! You can fight! And you can...
[Peter crows and bows to Rufio. Rufio does the same and the lost boys cheer]

[starts to descend the steps on his ship but stops]
Where's the carpet, Smee?
Oh! Sorry, sir.
[Smee stamps his foot once and a red carpet appears on the stairs]
[in the Museum where all clocks are destroyed. Hook hands Jack a hammer to destroy his father's watch]
You know you want to. Give it a try. Go on.
This is for... never letting me blow bubbles in my chocolate milk!
[smashes his father's watch]
Good form! Bravo!
[claps]
Isn't that wonderful?
This is for never letting me jump on my own bed!
[smashes another clock]
Make time stand still, laddie.
For always making promises and breaking them!
[smashes another clock]
For never doing anything with me.
[smashes another clock]
For a father who's never there, Jack? Jack, for a father who didn't save you on the ship.

[starts to cry]
Who wouldn't save us...
Who *couldn't* save you, Jack.

[tearfully]
Well, he - he wouldn't. And he didn't even try. He was there and we were there and he wouldn't try.
[pulls his cap down as he cries]

When the time comes, do you want to be saved? Now, don't you answer now. No, no, no, no, no. Now it's time to be whatever you want to be. Put behind you any thoughts of home; that place of broken promises.
That what?
Have I ever made a promise, Jack... I have not kept?
[gives him a baseball]
Have I, son?
I fancy them shiny shoes for my booty!
Well, I think you can get them at Armani.
It's okay. Hang on, son. I'm coming, sweetheart.
[begins to climb up a rope ladder]
Someone give me a hand.
I already have.
[Peter and Moira are in an argument when Peter's cell phone rings]
It's Brad, Moira. I gotta take this call. I've gotta fix this.
No, you've got to fix your family first.

Peter. I swear to you wherever you go, wherever you are, I vow there will always be daggers bearing notes signed James Hook. They will be flung into doors of your children's children's children, do you hear me?
What do you want, old man?
Just you.

[gets up and grabs Captain Hook's hook]
I wanna tear your hook off!

[looks from Jack to Maggie]
Easy.
I hate... I hate you, Mr. Hook!

[laughs]
What did I tell you, Smee? No little children love me.
Yes, they do. Come on, you.
[grabs Maggie]
You're depressin' the Captain.
Jack, you listen to me! Never let him make you forget! Never forget mommy and daddy!
Maggie.
Think of a way to run home, Jack! Run home!
Run home?
Jack.
[puts his hook in front of his face; Jack's eyes widen a bit]
You are home.
[laughs]
Right?

[flying to England on a plane in turbulence]
I'm not gonna make it to my next birthday.
You're not gonna die without a phone and fax machine.
I'm halfway there. I got the phone in my briefcase.
Jack, my word is my bond.
Yeah, junk bonds!
[he hits the ceiling door in the plane with his ball, and causes the oxygen masks to drop down and scare Peter half to death]
What in the hell's the matter with you? When are you gonna stop acting like a child?

[laughs]
I am a child.
Grow up.

[rings the bell while the duel goes on]
If there's anybody not fighting, get here quick!

[while fighting Hook]
Lookie Lookie, I've got Hookie.

[Peter notices that he looks exactly like Smee]
Hello. Having trouble with the missus? You will have by the time you get home.

[wielding his sword ready to fight Peter, after Rufio's death]
Are you ready for me Peter? Come on, humor the Hook.

[Jack is angry at his Dad and tossing his baseball to the ceiling and catching it]
Will you stop doing that? You could break a window.
They're double-layered, you can't break 'em.
[he demonstrates his point by banging his ball against the glass]

[confiscating the ball]
Give me that!

[in disbelief]
You're afraid of getting sucked out!

[defensively]
No, I'm not!

[insisting]
Yes, you are. You're afraid of getting sucked out.
If less is more, there's no end to me, Peter Pan.

[contemplating]
Smee, I've just had a sublime vision. All the jagged parts of my life have come together to form a complete an mystical... whole. An epiphany.
A "piphy"-what?
My life is over!
Does that mean you've lost your appetite?
Yes. Goodbye.

[when Peter sees Wendy after ten years]
I told you, gran, I'd get him here, by hook or by crook.
[dancing and singing at the same time]
Jack! Jack! He's our man. If he can't do it, no one can!
Mama wants a new pair of shoes. Drive me home, Jack!

[while the children are running around making a noise, shouting into the phone]
Wait a minute. You're telling me a 10-inch owl has a 50-mile mating radius? Why don't they just fornicate someplace else? What, a five billion dollar deal falling apart because of this? Why doesn't somebody just shoot me in the head?

[making a gun gesture with his hands]
Bang, bang!

[abandoning call, shouts]
Will everybody just shut up!

[backing away in fright]
I'm sorry.
And leave me alone for one moment! Moira, get 'em outta here, will you? I'm on the phone call of my life!

[exits Maggie and Jack]
Come on, Jack, come on. Out, out out.
I've forgotten how to fly.
Yes, well... one does.
[Hook hangs Maggie and Jack from a net atop the mast]
I'll make you a deal, Mr. Chairman-of-the-Board. Fly up there and touch the outstretched fingers of your frightened children, and I'll set them free.
I can't fly!
Come on, explode out of there! Stop the charade! Free you children!
Help, daddy!

[Peter whispers to Hook's ear]
I beg your pardon?

[inaudible whisper]
I have a real problem with heights.
You must be joking.
[he laughs]
Peter Pan has a real problem with heights!
[Hook and the other pirates burst out laughing]
I'm not Peter Pan.

[sadly]
Don't leave us Peter, and don't say goodbye.
What's goodbye?

[voice breaking]
It's going away, that's what it is. Forgetting about us all over again.
No, my Lost Boys, I'll never leave you, never. So who will I leave in charge?
[Peter takes out his sword and tries to figure out who will be the new Pan, he chooses Thud Butt]
Now I want you to take care of everything that's smaller than you.
Okay.
Then who do I look after?
Neverbugs - little ones.
[Peter backs away and flies off as the Lost Boys watch him as they all smile]
That was a great game!

[flies away]
Thank you for believing.

[shouts]
Goodnight, Neverland!
[Maggie and the four Lost Boys try to escape out the ship]
Where do you think you're going? Get away from that window!
[Peter and Hook are dueling]
Good form, old man.
[Hook traps Peter and grinds his hook near his face]

You know you're not really Peter Pan, don't you? This is only a dream. When you wake up, you'll just be Peter Banning, a cold, selfish man who drinks too much, who's obsessed with success, and runs and hides from his wife and children!
I believe in you.
I believe in you.
I believe in you, Peter.
I believe in you.
You are the Pan.
You're Peter Pan.
I believe in you... Peter Pan.
[Peter pushes Hook off and returns his sword. As Hook takes it, he slices Peter's arm with his hook]
Bad form!
Jack, stop!
Finally, I'm going to kill Peter Pan, that cocky boy who cut off my hand and fed it to the crocodile!
[pirates cheer]
And who killed that cunning crocodile?
Hook!
Who stuffed him?
Hook!
Who made him into a quiet clock?
Hook!
Who went into the other world and stole Pan's children?
Hook!
And who didn't believe I could do it? Who doubted me? Who amongst us does not belong? Someone here does not belong, a stranger amongst the loyal. I will weed you out!

I think your mother reads to you every night in order to stupefy you to sleep. So she and daddy can sit down for three measly minutes without you and your mindless, inexhaustible, unstoppable, repetitive and nagging demands. "He took my toy." "She hit my bear." "I want a potty." "I want a cookie." "I want to stay up." I want, I want, I want, me, me, me, me, mine, mine, mine, mine, now, now, now... can't you understand child? They tell you stories to shut you up.
Who's the shrub?

[at the end, watching as Peter flies back home]
That was a great game.

[to Rufio]
You are a very ill-mannered young man. Do you know that?
